titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William Coleman research files CBHM.0032
titlestmt.author: Dee Bowers

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-09-18 17:41:42 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: Primary and secondary sources, notes, correspondence, and other documents relating to William "Bill" Coleman's research into the history of the slave trade.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into three series by type: primary sources, secondary sources, and Coleman's notes and correspondence. For simplicity, the archivist sorted pre-1900 documents as primary sources and post-1900 sources as secondary sources. Each series is further sub-divided by type. There are additional arrangement notes at the sub-series and folder level where appropriate.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: William R. "Bill" Coleman was born in 1947. He earned a BA in Political Science from the University of Wisconsin Madison in 1969 and a JD from New York Law School in 1972, after which he practiced law professionally until his retirement in 2006. He was elected to the board of the Brooklyn Historical Society in 1986 and served for 16 years before resigning in 2001, though he and his wife continued to support the Society. He was the honoree of the Society's 4th annual library dinner in 2008, and his speech from that occasion is included in this collection. He was also involved with the Brooklyn Bar Association, the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue, and the Prospect Park Alliance. In addition, Coleman was an independent researcher and historian who planned to write a book on the history of the African slave trade in America.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Users of this collection should note that research notes and files represent a work in progress, or an interpretation that might change over time. History is always subject to debate and new inquiry. This collection represents a researcher's interpretation of the archival material, and we invite you to look at the relevant original material, either at CBH or elsewhere.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); William Coleman research files, CBHM.0032, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was rearranged for clarity and ease of use, but a listing of Coleman's original folder headings and order is preserved in the accession file. The archivist discarded duplicate copies of materials with no distinguishing markings, but retained duplicates if they had unique markings or notes from Coleman. Original folders were discarded and replaced with acid-free archival folders, but in cases where Coleman had made notes on a folder, it was photocopied and filed with the folder's contents. Email addresses of Coleman's correspondents were redacted for privacy.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: William R. Coleman papers ARC.018 (papers of Coleman's grandfather)
William R. Coleman collection of New York City waterfront pollution slides (2012.017)

CBH's Black History research guide includes detailed information on collections at CBH that document the history of enslavement in Brooklyn, and the online project In Pursuit of Freedom (https://pursuitoffreedom.org/) documents abolitionist history in Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the research files of William Coleman on the history of the slave trade. The collection is divided into three series: primary sources, secondary sources, and William Coleman notes and correspondence. Series 1: Primary Sources consists primarily of modern copies of pre-1900 sources, though there are some original documents. Series 2: Secondary Sources is largly computer printouts of post-1900 sources, though there are also photocopies of books and clippings. Series 3 contains both printed emails as well as typed and handwritten notes.

Primary source documents include books and articles, sermons and addresses, legal and government documents, and newspaper clippings. Secondary source documents include articles, books and book excerpts, indexes, lists, and guides, reviews, and theses and dissertations.

Though Coleman's overarching research topic was the African slave trade, this collection also includes significant materials on several related topics. These include the Oaksmith family (accused slave trader Appleton Oaksmith and his parents, the writers Seba Smith and Elizabeth Oakes Smith), the case of Nathaniel Gordon, Southern businessman Gazaway Bugg Lamar, and the slave trade from Asia.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In addition to clippings, this file includes printouts of 1850s-60s register entries for the ships Norway, Wm. M. Groton, Flora Temple, and Sunny South, arranged alphabetically by ship name. There is also a page of Coleman's notes as well as printouts about Amoy, China and the ship Sea Witch.
